title: Fragments & Run-On Sentences
description: Can you spot the sentence fragments and run-on sentences? Sharpen your writing skills with this quiz!

questions.question: Which of the following is a sentence fragment?
options: Running through the park on a sunny day.
She went to the store.
The birds sang loudly.
We enjoyed the concert.

questions.question: Which sentence is a run-on?
options: Although I love cooking, she loves baking.
I love cooking. She loves baking.
I love cooking she loves baking.
I love cooking, and she loves baking.

questions.question: What is a sentence fragment?
options: A sentence with a spelling error
A sentence with too many words
An incomplete sentence missing a subject, verb, or complete thought
A sentence that ends with a question mark

questions.question: Which is a comma splice (a type of run-on)?
options: After going home, I ate dinner.
I went home, I ate dinner.
I went home, and I ate dinner.
I went home. I ate dinner.

questions.question: How can you fix a run-on sentence?
options: Add a period and capitalize the next word
Add a comma and coordinating conjunction
Use a semicolon
All of the above

questions.question: Which is a complete sentence?
options: The sun came out.
While waiting for the bus.
Because she was late.
After the rain stopped.

questions.question: Which is a fragment?
options: She smiled.
It rained.
The book on the table near the window.
Stop!

questions.question: Fix the run-on: 'He was tired he went to bed early.'
options: He was tired he, went to bed early.
He was tired he went, to bed early.
He was tired, he went to bed early.
He was tired, so he went to bed early.

questions.question: Why is 'Because I said so.' a fragment when standing alone?
options: It starts with 'because,' making it a dependent clause.
It has no verb.
It is too short.
It ends with a period.

questions.question: Which sentence is correct?
options: The movie was great; I loved the ending.
The movie was great I loved the ending.
The movie was great, I loved the ending.
The movie was great I, loved the ending.

questions.question: A complete sentence must have ___.
options: At least ten words
An adjective and an adverb
A subject and a predicate expressing a complete thought
A comma and a period

questions.question: Which is a fused sentence (run-on with no punctuation)?
options: She danced, and he sang.
She danced; he sang.
She danced he sang.
She danced. He sang.

questions.question: Fix the fragment: 'Walking to the store on a rainy afternoon.'
options: Walking to the store, on a rainy afternoon.
Walking to the store on a rainy afternoon, she forgot her umbrella.
To the store, walking on a rainy afternoon.
Walking, to the store on a rainy afternoon.

questions.question: Which is NOT a way to fix a comma splice?
options: Remove the subject from the second clause
Add a conjunction after the comma
Replace the comma with a semicolon
Replace the comma with a period

questions.question: Can a single word be a complete sentence?
options: Only if it is a noun.
Only in informal writing.
No, sentences must have at least three words.
Yes, imperative sentences like 'Stop!' are complete.
